  3. (*                                 OCaml                                  *)
  4. (*                                                                        *)

  16. (* Common subexpression elimination by value numbering over extended
  17.    basic blocks. *)

  19. open Mach

  21. ‌type valnum = int

  23. (* Classification of operations *)

  25. ‌type op_class =
  26.   | Op_pure           (* pure arithmetic, produce one or several result *)
  27.   | Op_checkbound     (* checkbound-style: no result, can raise an exn *)
  28.   | Op_load of Asttypes.mutable_flag (* memory load *)
  29.   | Op_store of bool  (* memory store, false = init, true = assign *)
  30.   | Op_other   (* anything else that does not allocate nor store in memory *)

  32. (* We maintain sets of equations of the form
  33.        valnums = operation(valnums)
  34.    plus a mapping from registers to valnums (value numbers). *)

  36. ‌type rhs = operation * valnum array

  38. module Equations = struct
  39.   module Rhs_map =
  40. ‌‌    Map.Make(struct type t = rhs let compare = Stdlib.compare end)

  42. ‌  type 'a t =
  43.     { mutable_load_equations : 'a Rhs_map.t;
  44.       other_equations : 'a Rhs_map.t }

  46. ‌  let empty =
  47.     { mutable_load_equations = Rhs_map.empty;
  48.       other_equations = Rhs_map.empty }

  50. ‌  let add op_class op v m =
  51.     match op_class with
  52.     | Op_load Mutable ->
  53.       { m with mutable_load_equations =
  54.                  Rhs_map.add op v m.mutable_load_equations }
  55.     | _ ->
  56.       { m with other_equations = Rhs_map.add op v m.other_equations }

  58. ‌  let find op_class op m =
  59.     match op_class with
  60.     | Op_load Mutable ->
  61.       Rhs_map.find op m.mutable_load_equations
  62.     | _ ->
  63.       Rhs_map.find op m.other_equations

  65. ‌  let remove_mutable_loads m =
  66.     { mutable_load_equations = Rhs_map.empty;
  67.       other_equations = m.other_equations }
  68. end

  70. ‌type numbering =
  71.   { num_next: int;                      (* next fresh value number *)
  72.     num_eqs: valnum array Equations.t;  (* mapping rhs -> valnums *)
  73.     num_reg: valnum Reg.Map.t }         (* mapping register -> valnum *)

  75. ‌let empty_numbering =
  76.   { num_next = 0; num_eqs = Equations.empty; num_reg = Reg.Map.empty }

  78. (** Generate a fresh value number [v] and associate it to register [r].
  79.   Returns a pair [(n',v)] with the updated value numbering [n']. *)

  81. ‌let fresh_valnum_reg n r =
  82.   let v = n.num_next in
  83.   ({n with num_next = v + 1; num_reg = Reg.Map.add r v n.num_reg}, v)

  85. (* Same, for a set of registers [rs]. *)

  87. ‌let array_fold_transf (f: numbering -> 'a -> numbering * 'b) n (a: 'a array)
  88.                       : numbering * 'b array =
  89.   match Array.length a with
  90.   | 0 -> (n, [||])
  91.   | 1 -> let (n', b) = f n a.(0) in (n', [|b|])
  92.   | l -> let b = Array.make l 0 and n = ref n in
  93.          for i = 0 to l - 1 do
  94.            let (n', x) = f !n a.(i) in
  95.            b.(i) <- x; n := n'
  96.          done;
  97.          (!n, b)

  99. ‌let fresh_valnum_regs n rs =
  100.   array_fold_transf fresh_valnum_reg n rs

  102. (** [valnum_reg n r] returns the value number for the contents of
  103.   register [r].  If none exists, a fresh value number is returned
  104.   and associated with register [r].  The possibly updated numbering
  105.   is also returned.  [valnum_regs] is similar, but for an array of
  106.   registers. *)

  108. ‌let valnum_reg n r =
  109.   try
  110.     (n, Reg.Map.find r n.num_reg)
  111.   with Not_found ->
  112.     fresh_valnum_reg n r

  114. ‌let valnum_regs n rs =
  115.   array_fold_transf valnum_reg n rs

  117. (* Look up the set of equations for an equation with the given rhs.
  118.    Return [Some res] if there is one, where [res] is the lhs. *)

  120. ‌let find_equation op_class n rhs =
  121.   try
  122.     Some(Equations.find op_class rhs n.num_eqs)
  123.   with Not_found ->
  124.     None

  126. (* Find a register containing the given value number. *)

  128. ‌let find_reg_containing n v =
  129.   Reg.Map.fold (fun r v' res -> if v' = v then Some r else res)
  130.                n.num_reg None

  132. (* Find a set of registers containing the given value numbers. *)

  134. ‌let find_regs_containing n vs =
  135.   match Array.length vs with
  136.   | 0 -> Some [||]
  137.   | 1 -> begin match find_reg_containing n vs.(0) with
  138.          | None -> None
  139.          | Some r -> Some [|r|]
  140.          end
  141.   | l -> let rs = Array.make l Reg.dummy in
  142.          begin try
  143.            for i = 0 to l - 1 do
  144.              match find_reg_containing n vs.(i) with
  145.              | None -> raise Exit
  146.              | Some r -> rs.(i) <- r
  147.            done;
  148.            Some rs
  149.          with Exit ->
  150.            None
  151.          end

  153. (* Associate the given value number to the given result register,
  154.    without adding new equations. *)

  156. let set_known_reg n r v =
  157.   { n with num_reg = Reg.Map.add r v n.num_reg }

  159. (* Associate the given value numbers to the given result registers,
  160.    without adding new equations. *)

  162. ‌let array_fold2 f n a1 a2 =
  163.   let l = Array.length a1 in
  164.   assert (l = Array.length a2);
  165.   let n = ref n in
  166.   for i = 0 to l - 1 do n := f !n a1.(i) a2.(i) done;
  167.   !n

  169. ‌let set_known_regs n rs vs =
  170.   array_fold2 set_known_reg n rs vs

  172. (* Record the effect of a move: no new equations, but the result reg
  173.    maps to the same value number as the argument reg. *)

  175. ‌let set_move n src dst =
  176.   let (n1, v) = valnum_reg n src in
  177.   { n1 with num_reg = Reg.Map.add dst v n1.num_reg }

  179. (* Record the equation [fresh valnums = rhs] and associate the given
  180.    result registers [rs] to [fresh valnums]. *)

  182. ‌let set_fresh_regs n rs rhs op_class =
  183.   let (n1, vs) = fresh_valnum_regs n rs in
  184.   { n1 with num_eqs = Equations.add op_class rhs vs n.num_eqs }

  186. (* Forget everything we know about the given result registers,
  187.    which are receiving unpredictable values at run-time. *)

  189. ‌let set_unknown_regs n rs =
  190.   { n with num_reg = Array.fold_right Reg.Map.remove rs n.num_reg }

  192. (* Keep only the equations satisfying the given predicate. *)

  194. ‌let remove_mutable_load_numbering n =
  195.   { n with num_eqs = Equations.remove_mutable_loads n.num_eqs }

  197. (* Forget everything we know about registers of type [Addr]. *)

  199. ‌let kill_addr_regs n =
  200.   { n with num_reg =
  201.               Reg.Map.filter (fun r _n -> r.Reg.typ <> Cmm.Addr) n.num_reg }

  203. (* Prepend a set of moves before [i] to assign [srcs] to [dsts].  *)

  205. ‌let insert_single_move i src dst = instr_cons (Iop Imove) [|src|] [|dst|] i

  207. ‌let insert_move srcs dsts i =
  208.   match Array.length srcs with
  209.   | 0 -> i
  210.   | 1 -> instr_cons (Iop Imove) srcs dsts i
  211.   | _ -> (* Parallel move: first copy srcs into tmps one by one,
  212.             then copy tmps into dsts one by one *)
  213.          let tmps = Reg.createv_like srcs in
  214.          let i1 = array_fold2 insert_single_move i tmps dsts in
  215.          array_fold2 insert_single_move i1 srcs tmps

  217. class cse_generic = object (self)

  219. (* Default classification of operations.  Can be overridden in
  220.    processor-specific files to classify specific operations better. *)

  222. method class_of_operation op =
  223.   match op with
  224.   | Imove | Ispill | Ireload -> assert false   (* treated specially *)
  225.   | Iconst_int _ | Iconst_float _ | Iconst_symbol _ -> Op_pure
  226.   | Icall_ind | Icall_imm _ | Itailcall_ind | Itailcall_imm _
  227.   | Iextcall _ | Iopaque -> assert false       (* treated specially *)
  228.   | Istackoffset _ -> Op_other
  229.   | Iload { mutability } -> Op_load mutability
  230.   | Istore(_,_,asg) -> Op_store asg
  231.   | Ialloc _ | Ipoll _ -> assert false     (* treated specially *)
  232.   | Iintop(Icheckbound) -> Op_checkbound
  233.   | Iintop _ -> Op_pure
  234.   | Iintop_imm(Icheckbound, _) -> Op_checkbound
  235.   | Iintop_imm(_, _) -> Op_pure
  236.   | Icompf _ | Inegf | Iabsf | Iaddf | Isubf | Imulf | Idivf
  237.   | Ifloatofint | Iintoffloat -> Op_pure
  238.   | Ispecific _ -> Op_other
  239.   | Idls_get -> Op_load Mutable

  241. (* Operations that are so cheap that it isn't worth factoring them. *)
  242. method is_cheap_operation op =
  243.   match op with
  244.   | Iconst_int _ -> true
  245.   | _ -> false

  247. (* Forget all equations involving mutable memory loads.
  248.    Performed after a non-initializing store *)

  250. method private kill_loads n =
  251.   remove_mutable_load_numbering n

  253. (* Perform CSE on the given instruction [i] and its successors.
  254.    [n] is the value numbering current at the beginning of [i]. *)

  256. method private cse n i =
  257.   match i.desc with
  258.   | Iend | Ireturn | Iop(Itailcall_ind) | Iop(Itailcall_imm _)
  259.   | Iexit _ | Iraise _ ->
  260.       i
  261.   | Iop (Imove | Ispill | Ireload) ->
  262.       (* For moves, we associate the same value number to the result reg
  263.          as to the argument reg. *)
  264.       let n1 = set_move n i.arg.(0) i.res.(0) in
  265.       {i with next = self#cse n1 i.next}
  266.   | Iop (Icall_ind | Icall_imm _ | Iextcall _) ->
  267.       (* For function calls, we should at least forget:
  268.          - equations involving memory loads, since the callee can
  269.            perform arbitrary memory stores;
  270.          - equations involving arithmetic operations that can
  271.            produce [Addr]-typed derived pointers into the heap
  272.            (see below for Ialloc);
  273.          - mappings from hardware registers to value numbers,
  274.            since the callee does not preserve these registers.
  275.          That doesn't leave much usable information: checkbounds
  276.          could be kept, but won't be usable for CSE as one of their
  277.          arguments is always a memory load.  For simplicity, we
  278.          just forget everything. *)
  279.       {i with next = self#cse empty_numbering i.next}
  280.   | Iop Iopaque ->
  281.       (* Assume arbitrary side effects from Iopaque *)
  282.       {i with next = self#cse empty_numbering i.next}
  283.   | Iop (Ialloc _) | Iop (Ipoll _) ->
  284.       (* For allocations, we must avoid extending the live range of a
  285.          pseudoregister across the allocation if this pseudoreg
  286.          is a derived heap pointer (a pointer into the heap that does
  287.          not point to the beginning of a Caml block).  PR#6484 is an
  288.          example of this situation.  Such pseudoregs have type [Addr].
  289.          Pseudoregs with types other than [Addr] can be kept.
  290.          Moreover, allocations and polls can trigger the asynchronous execution
  291.          of arbitrary Caml code (finalizer, signal handler, context
  292.          switch), which can contain non-initializing stores.
  293.          Hence, all equations over mutable loads must be removed. *)
  294.        let n1 = kill_addr_regs (self#kill_loads n) in
  295.        let n2 = set_unknown_regs n1 i.res in
  296.        {i with next = self#cse n2 i.next}
  297.   | Iop op ->
  298.       begin match self#class_of_operation op with
  299.       | (Op_pure | Op_checkbound | Op_load _) as op_class ->
  300.           let (n1, varg) = valnum_regs n i.arg in
  301.           let n2 = set_unknown_regs n1 (Proc.destroyed_at_oper i.desc) in
  302.           begin match find_equation op_class n1 (op, varg) with
  303.           | Some vres ->
  304.               (* This operation was computed earlier. *)
  305.               (* Are there registers that hold the results computed earlier? *)
  306.               begin match find_regs_containing n1 vres with
  307.               | Some res when (not (self#is_cheap_operation op)) ->
  308.                   (* We can replace res <- op args with r <- move res,
  309.                      provided res are stable (non-volatile) registers.
  310.                      If the operation is very cheap to compute, e.g.
  311.                      an integer constant, don't bother. *)
  312.                   let n3 = set_known_regs n1 i.res vres in
  313.                   (* This is n1 above and not n2 because the move
  314.                      does not destroy any regs *)
  315.                   insert_move res i.res (self#cse n3 i.next)
  316.               | _ ->
  317.                   (* We already computed the operation but lost its
  318.                      results.  Associate the result registers to
  319.                      the result valnums of the previous operation. *)
  320.                   let n3 = set_known_regs n2 i.res vres in
  321.                   {i with next = self#cse n3 i.next}
  322.               end
  323.           | None ->
  324.               (* This operation produces a result we haven't seen earlier. *)
  325.               let n3 = set_fresh_regs n2 i.res (op, varg) op_class in
  326.               {i with next = self#cse n3 i.next}
  327.           end
  328.       | Op_store false | Op_other ->
  329.           (* An initializing store or an "other" operation do not invalidate
  330.              any equations, but we do not know anything about the results. *)
  331.          let n1 = set_unknown_regs n (Proc.destroyed_at_oper i.desc) in
  332.          let n2 = set_unknown_regs n1 i.res in
  333.          {i with next = self#cse n2 i.next}
  334.       | Op_store true ->
  335.           (* A non-initializing store can invalidate
  336.              anything we know about prior mutable loads. *)
  337.          let n1 = set_unknown_regs n (Proc.destroyed_at_oper i.desc) in
  338.          let n2 = set_unknown_regs n1 i.res in
  339.          let n3 = self#kill_loads n2 in
  340.          {i with next = self#cse n3 i.next}
  341.       end
  342.   (* For control structures, we set the numbering to empty at every
  343.      join point, but propagate the current numbering across fork points. *)
  344.   | Iifthenelse(test, ifso, ifnot) ->
  345.      let n1 = set_unknown_regs n (Proc.destroyed_at_oper i.desc) in
  346.       {i with desc = Iifthenelse(test, self#cse n1 ifso, self#cse n1 ifnot);
  347.               next = self#cse empty_numbering i.next}
  348.   | Iswitch(index, cases) ->
  349.      let n1 = set_unknown_regs n (Proc.destroyed_at_oper i.desc) in
  350.       {i with desc = Iswitch(index, Array.map (self#cse n1) cases);
  351.               next = self#cse empty_numbering i.next}
  352.   | Icatch(rec_flag, handlers, body) ->
  353.       let aux (nfail, handler) =
  354.         nfail, self#cse empty_numbering handler
  355.       in
  356.       {i with desc = Icatch(rec_flag, List.map aux handlers, self#cse n body);
  357.               next = self#cse empty_numbering i.next}
  358.   | Itrywith(body, handler) ->
  359.       {i with desc = Itrywith(self#cse n body,
  360.                               self#cse empty_numbering handler);
  361.               next = self#cse empty_numbering i.next}

  363. method fundecl f =
  364.   (* CSE can trigger bad register allocation behaviors, see MPR#7630 *)
  365.   if List.mem Cmm.No_CSE f.fun_codegen_options then
  366.     f
  367.   else
  368.     {f with fun_body = self#cse empty_numbering f.fun_body }

  370. end
